#: Robert Watkins changed the world a bit at a time by saying on  10/19/200=
5 9:34 AM :#
> On 10/19/05, C=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 <cbeust@...>=
 wrote:
>> Still, if you're calling run(), it means you already have an ins=
tance of
>> your test, right? And then, the test methods will all be invoke=
d on
>> different instances than the one you invoked run() on...
> 
> It's =
my turn to go huh, Cedric... how would invoking run on one
> instance cause=
 it to run other instances?
> 
> A TestRunner has Tests. It calls run(TestR=
esult) on them. It makes
> instances once. It can call run(TestResult) as m=
any times as it wants
> to, without creating the instances again.
> 
> Test=
Results have references to the tests in them. So they can provide
> a faili=
ng TestCase instance so that you can call run() directly on it,
> allowing =
just the one instance to run again.
> 
> It's not that this is a big deal o=
r anything, it's just that it's
> convenient. In TestNG, you would need a w=
ay to identify exactly the
> test that failed... with parameterised tests, =
that means you need to
> identify the parameter. That wouldn't be hard eith=
er: add an index to
> the report or something.
> --
>                "Softw=
are is too expensive to build cheaply"
> Robert Watkins           http://tw=
asink.net/           robertdw@...
> 

Are you saying that f.e. Ecli=
pse plugin is keepin' loaded in the memory all the failed test 
instances j=
ust to be sure you can press rerun failed?
